Pre-Game Insights: After using a combined 16 pitchers in Game 4, the Phillies and the D-backs understand that Game 5 will likely come down to which team receives the best and longest performance from its ace.
Zack Wheeler and Zac Gallen, who matched up in Game 1, will return to the mound for Game 5 after the D-backs evened the series, 2-2, with a come-from-behind victory.
Phillies manager Rob Thomson emphasized the importance of having their ace on the mound for Game 5.
Wheeler has been Philadelphia’s ace with a 2.37 ERA and 26 strikeouts in three postseason games.
Gallen was Arizona’s ace during the regular season and is expected to give the team length in Game 5.
Game 5 will be at 8 p.m. ET (5 MST) on Saturday at Chase Field, airing on TBS.
Phillies starting pitcher Zack Wheeler has a 2.37 ERA in three starts this postseason and a 2.63 ERA in nine career postseason starts.
D-backs starting pitcher Zac Gallen allowed five runs in Game 1 but had a strong regular season with a 3.47 ERA.
Phillies lineup includes Kyle Schwarber, Trea Turner, Bryce Harper, Alec Bohm, Bryson Stott, J.T. Realmuto, Nick Castellanos, Brandon Marsh, and Johan Rojas.
D-backs lineup includes Corbin Carroll, Ketel Marte, Gabriel Moreno, Christian Walker, Pavin Smith, Lourdes Gurriel Jr., Alek Thomas, Evan Longoria, and Geraldo Perdomo.
Phillies bullpen usage is in question after back-to-back losses and heavy usage of key relievers.
D-backs bullpen is expected to be available for Game 5 despite heavy usage in Game 4.
Phillies' Rhys Hoskins is on the 60-day injured list but could be added to the roster if the team advances to the World Series.
D-backs' Jake McCarthy is not expected back after suffering a strained right oblique.
Phillies' Trea Turner has a hit in each of his first 10 games this postseason.
Phillies' Kyle Schwarber hit his fourth homer of the series in Game 4, setting a record for most postseason homers by a left-handed batter.
D-backs' Gabriel Moreno drove home two runs in Game 4, including the game-winner.
D-backs' Alek Thomas hit a pinch-hit two-run homer in Game 4.
D-backs' Ketel Marte has hit safely in 13 straight postseason games, tying for the second-longest hitting streak to open a postseason career.
